description: Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems [reference]. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate (MCSA) is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The MCSA: Windows 7 covers topics that are “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows desktops in a corporate or enterprise environment. Most people know how to use Windows in a home environment. However, there are many features under the hood that are designed for environments with a large quantity of computers. The MCSA dives in to those and gives the learner a whole new toolbox for ensuring their computing environment is functional and stable.
name: MCSA Windows 7 - 70-680
subtitle: Windows 7, Configuring

episodes.description: Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate (MCSA) is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The MCSA: Windows 7 covers topics that are “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows desktops in a corporate or enterprise environment. Most people know how to use Windows in a home environment. However, there are many features under the hood that are designed for environments with a large quantity of computers. The MCSA dives in to those and gives the learner a whole new toolbox for ensuring their computing environment is functional and stable.
episodes.title: Introduction to Windows 7
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:05,409
[NOISE] We want to take a moment to talk

2
00:00:05,409 --> 00:00:10,254
about the 70-680 exam and

3
00:00:10,254 --> 00:00:14,745
what it means to you, right.

4
00:00:14,745 --> 00:00:16,102
So Windows 7 and you.

5
00:00:16,102 --> 00:00:16,614
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

6
00:00:16,614 --> 00:00:19,310
>> For those of you that are seeking

7
00:00:19,310 --> 00:00:24,090
the knowledge and
validation that shows that you're aware

8
00:00:24,090 --> 00:00:28,910
of how to work with Windows 7, well, the
Microsoft 70-680 exam is the one for you.

9
00:00:28,910 --> 00:00:32,960
This exam covers a wide variety of
topics pertaining to Windows 7,

10
00:00:32,960 --> 00:00:37,510
and not just Windows 7 in terms of
how to use it like end user style,

11
00:00:37,510 --> 00:00:39,360
but network administrator style.

12
00:00:39,360 --> 00:00:43,940
So how to install and deploy Windows 7,
how to manage and maintain Windows 7 and

13
00:00:43,940 --> 00:00:47,310
how to secure it and
keep it operational in your environment.

14
00:00:47,310 --> 00:00:52,730
This is valuable information that anybody
is going to need to work in a corporate or

15
00:00:52,730 --> 00:00:55,344
enterprise environment where you're
supporting Windows 7 workstations.

16
00:00:56,602 --> 00:00:58,840
All right, so
to get an idea of what the exam is like,

17
00:00:58,840 --> 00:01:01,990
let's take a look at the official
Microsoft page for the exam.

18
00:01:01,990 --> 00:01:03,470
So I've got it pulled up right here,

19
00:01:03,470 --> 00:01:06,140
and you'll see some basic
information about it.

20
00:01:06,140 --> 00:01:09,210
The actual title for
the exam is Windows 7, Configuring.

21
00:01:10,610 --> 00:01:13,460
Why they reversed these
things is beyond me.

22
00:01:13,460 --> 00:01:19,860
But it's nice because it is one set of
objectives, one exam, one certification.

23
00:01:19,860 --> 00:01:23,010
When you pass this exam,
you get the MCTS, or

24
00:01:23,010 --> 00:01:26,590
Microsoft Certified Technology Specialist,
in Windows 7.

25
00:01:26,590 --> 00:01:32,420
The exam objectives cover a variety of
things, and they break it down here.

26
00:01:32,420 --> 00:01:34,950
Let me just collapse all these so
we can get the overviews.

27
00:01:34,950 --> 00:01:39,730
And what you'll see looking at the list,
is we've got things,

28
00:01:39,730 --> 00:01:43,700
very basic, installing, upgrading and
migrating to Windows 7.

29
00:01:43,700 --> 00:01:46,670
All right, well,
installing Windows 7 is not very hard.

30
00:01:46,670 --> 00:01:50,120
But we'll see there's a variety of
ways to do it, and a variety of

31
00:01:50,120 --> 00:01:53,700
concerns we have depending on what
operating system we may be coming from.

32
00:01:53,700 --> 00:01:57,657
If we're coming from Windows XP or
Vista or wherever, right?

33
00:01:59,370 --> 00:02:02,610
We'll also see other things
like Deploying Windows 7.

34
00:02:02,610 --> 00:02:05,140
This is talking about
image-based deployment.

35
00:02:05,140 --> 00:02:09,220
So if you've got a thousand workstations
you need to install Windows 7 on,

36
00:02:09,220 --> 00:02:10,920
how can we do that.

37
00:02:10,920 --> 00:02:14,560
>> We also have the idea
of configuring hardware and

38
00:02:14,560 --> 00:02:16,340
other compatibility issues for us too.

39
00:02:16,340 --> 00:02:20,000
A lot of times when you are actually
a network administrator,

40
00:02:20,000 --> 00:02:24,580
you're moving from earlier operating
systems and earlier applications and

41
00:02:24,580 --> 00:02:27,650
we need to make sure that we can
ensure that they work with Windows 7.

42
00:02:27,650 --> 00:02:30,471
And so it gives us some different ways
to be able to troubleshoot them and

43
00:02:30,471 --> 00:02:31,270
to evaluate them and

44
00:02:31,270 --> 00:02:34,430
see if they're actually gonna be
appropriate for our Windows 7 environment.

45
00:02:36,253 --> 00:02:37,650
>> Yep.

46
00:02:37,650 --> 00:02:40,385
As well as we continue to move on.

47
00:02:40,385 --> 00:02:41,340
[CROSSTALK]
>> Yep, sorry.

48
00:02:41,340 --> 00:02:42,830
>> I have no idea what's happened here.

49
00:02:42,830 --> 00:02:44,390
But my mouse is no longer working.

50
00:02:44,390 --> 00:02:50,730
[LAUGH] It's lighting up, but it's not-
>> Oh, yeah, it's not letting you click.

51
00:02:50,730 --> 00:02:54,345
>> Yeah, I don't understand what I've
done, and I can't scroll anymore.

52
00:02:54,345 --> 00:03:01,715
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's like that web page locked up.

53
00:03:01,715 --> 00:03:04,450
Cuz outside of the browser
it's working just fine, but

54
00:03:04,450 --> 00:03:05,890
inside of the browser it was dead.

55
00:03:07,630 --> 00:03:08,689
You know what I might do?

56
00:03:08,689 --> 00:03:11,013
I could probably just pull up,
well, no those are our own notes.

57
00:03:11,013 --> 00:03:13,230
All right.

58
00:03:13,230 --> 00:03:14,495
>> [LAUGH]

59
00:03:21,418 --> 00:03:24,184
>> Okay, Jason.

60
00:03:26,920 --> 00:03:28,740
We were only what,
like a minute or two into that?

61
00:03:28,740 --> 00:03:29,770
Why don't we just restart?

62
00:03:29,770 --> 00:03:30,270
>> All right.

63
00:03:36,051 --> 00:03:40,200
[COUGH] [LAUGH]
>> Do you have it sorted out, or

64
00:03:40,200 --> 00:03:41,093
were you gonna?

65
00:03:41,093 --> 00:03:43,438
>> Well, yeah it's working now.

66
00:03:43,438 --> 00:03:45,615
We'll see if it [CROSSTALK]
>> If not,

67
00:03:45,615 --> 00:03:47,815
I've got mine up on the same page so.

68
00:03:47,815 --> 00:03:48,419
>> Okay, all right.

69
00:03:48,419 --> 00:03:49,011
>> Maybe we can.

70
00:03:49,011 --> 00:03:52,052
>> So, if I do like a thumbs down or
whatever,

71
00:03:52,052 --> 00:03:55,942
we'll cut to Ronnie's,
but otherwise I've got it.

72
00:03:55,942 --> 00:03:57,022
Okay.

73
00:03:57,022 --> 00:03:58,496
Take two.

74
00:03:58,496 --> 00:04:06,819
[MUSIC]

75
00:04:06,819 --> 00:04:11,574
In this video we're gonna take
a look at the Microsoft 70-680 exam,

76
00:04:11,574 --> 00:04:14,800
which is the Windows 7 configuring exam.

77
00:04:14,800 --> 00:04:19,190
I like to refer to this as the show
that almost wasn't, right?

78
00:04:19,190 --> 00:04:24,680
When ITProTV launched,
we launched in October of 2013,

79
00:04:24,680 --> 00:04:29,510
and Windows 8 had just come out, and
we launched our Windows 8 training, and

80
00:04:29,510 --> 00:04:31,980
we said, you know what,
let's not go backwards.

81
00:04:31,980 --> 00:04:34,620
Let's not do older software, older shows.

82
00:04:34,620 --> 00:04:37,190
Let's just focus on
the newer technologies.

83
00:04:37,190 --> 00:04:40,250
But we've gotten such a demand for
Windows 7, there's so

84
00:04:40,250 --> 00:04:42,455
many people out there
that still use it and

85
00:04:42,455 --> 00:04:47,530
it's their mainstream OS that we really
do need to go back and cover it.

86
00:04:47,530 --> 00:04:51,860
And so to do that we've brought in this
show right here, the Windows 7 show.

87
00:04:51,860 --> 00:04:56,230
We're gonna be tackling the 70-680 exam,
which is one of the nicer ones because

88
00:04:56,230 --> 00:05:01,600
it's one set of objectives,
one exam, one certification.

89
00:05:01,600 --> 00:05:07,930
When you pass the 70-680 exam,
you get the MCTS in Windows 7 configuring.

90
00:05:07,930 --> 00:05:11,300
That's the Microsoft Certified
Technology Specialist.

91
00:05:11,300 --> 00:05:12,840
It's a quick certification.

92
00:05:12,840 --> 00:05:14,740
You jump in, you pass it,
you get it on your resume.

93
00:05:14,740 --> 00:05:15,720
It's a real benefit.

94
00:05:15,720 --> 00:05:19,570
All right, so let's take a look
at some of the objectives that

95
00:05:19,570 --> 00:05:22,460
are on this exam that are things that
we're gonna be covering in this show.

96
00:05:23,630 --> 00:05:27,780
Well, the exam itself starts out where
you would logically think it would,

97
00:05:27,780 --> 00:05:31,850
installing and upgrading, well,
and migrating, to Windows 7.

98
00:05:31,850 --> 00:05:35,280
If you've got Windows XP,
Windows Vista and

99
00:05:35,280 --> 00:05:37,940
you want to get on Windows 7,
how do you do it?

100
00:05:37,940 --> 00:05:39,640
How do you install it, how do you upgrade?

101
00:05:39,640 --> 00:05:40,920
And so
that's were we kind of begin the show.

102
00:05:42,300 --> 00:05:45,240
>> The second objective that you
actually talk about here is the idea of

103
00:05:45,240 --> 00:05:46,600
deploying Windows 7.

104
00:05:46,600 --> 00:05:49,960
Now if you're a standalone user you may
not have heard this term before, but

105
00:05:49,960 --> 00:05:52,860
if you've been working in
the IT industry at all

106
00:05:52,860 --> 00:05:55,600
we tend to actually do what we
call image-based deployment.

107
00:05:55,600 --> 00:05:59,470
And so in here we actually show
how to actually create an image.

108
00:05:59,470 --> 00:06:01,870
How do we add in information
to that image, and

109
00:06:01,870 --> 00:06:04,370
how do we actually end up
pushing it out to computers.

110
00:06:04,370 --> 00:06:04,970
>> Yeah.

111
00:06:04,970 --> 00:06:06,820
And you know, the first one,
the first module,

112
00:06:06,820 --> 00:06:09,850
that's really talking about one machine.

113
00:06:09,850 --> 00:06:13,510
But the second module, that is hundreds,
thousands of machines, right?

114
00:06:13,510 --> 00:06:16,160
You may have a very,
very large environment.

115
00:06:16,160 --> 00:06:19,350
The third section is configuring
hardware and applications.

116
00:06:19,350 --> 00:06:22,720
So you've got Windows 7 installed,
what do you do now?

117
00:06:22,720 --> 00:06:26,820
Well, you likely have unique hardware,
no two computers, well that's

118
00:06:26,820 --> 00:06:29,910
not necessarily true, but most computers
have [LAUGH] various configurations.

119
00:06:29,910 --> 00:06:34,310
But you also have various applications
that you use as part of your business and

120
00:06:34,310 --> 00:06:35,700
your day to day operations.

121
00:06:35,700 --> 00:06:37,230
So how do we get those configured,

122
00:06:37,230 --> 00:06:39,330
how do we get them running,
and how do we support them?

123
00:06:40,380 --> 00:06:44,180
>> And the next session here on
configuring network connectivity.

124
00:06:44,180 --> 00:06:49,040
This is basic networking to ensure that
our Windows 7 environment will again run

125
00:06:49,040 --> 00:06:53,450
on top of our infrastructure, making sure
that we're familiar not only with the IPv4

126
00:06:53,450 --> 00:06:57,490
technologies, but as well as getting
introduced to the IPv6 technologies as

127
00:06:57,490 --> 00:07:00,770
well since we're actually moving fast
toward that particular migration.

128
00:07:02,510 --> 00:07:05,600
>> All right, the next section is
configuring access to resources.

129
00:07:05,600 --> 00:07:07,910
If you have files on your computer and

130
00:07:07,910 --> 00:07:10,960
you wanna share them with other people,
how do you do it?

131
00:07:10,960 --> 00:07:12,170
If you have a printer and

132
00:07:12,170 --> 00:07:15,820
you wanna make that printer available to
more than one machine, how do you do that?

133
00:07:15,820 --> 00:07:19,393
So we take a look at Windows 7 in
a workgroup or domain environment,

134
00:07:19,393 --> 00:07:23,470
where we're sharing resources between
systems, and whenever you do that,

135
00:07:23,470 --> 00:07:28,014
you need to control access, so how do you
limit people's access to those resources?

136
00:07:28,014 --> 00:07:29,935
>> Our next bigger objective here,

137
00:07:29,935 --> 00:07:34,395
on configuring mobile computing really
dives into the world of a couple of new

138
00:07:34,395 --> 00:07:38,729
technologies that again introduced
with Windows 7 and Server 2008.

139
00:07:38,729 --> 00:07:42,550
We talk a little bit about a technology
that we call BitLocker and

140
00:07:42,550 --> 00:07:47,410
BitLocker To Go, as well as the idea
of actually using direct access too.

141
00:07:47,410 --> 00:07:51,061
And so along with that,
of course, is the fast moving and

142
00:07:51,061 --> 00:07:53,685
fast diving world of Windows mobility.

143
00:07:53,685 --> 00:07:54,875
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

144
00:07:54,875 --> 00:07:58,460
Yeah, these are all topics that
really pertain to laptop users.

145
00:07:58,460 --> 00:08:02,190
People who might not be at the office,
they might be at home or out in the field.

146
00:08:02,190 --> 00:08:05,400
More and more people have laptops
instead of desktops, and so

147
00:08:05,400 --> 00:08:09,520
Microsoft has a dedicated
section addressing that.

148
00:08:09,520 --> 00:08:13,230
All right, next is monitoring and
maintaining systems that run Windows 7.

149
00:08:13,230 --> 00:08:18,290
Once we get everything set up and
operational, how do we keep it that way?

150
00:08:18,290 --> 00:08:20,740
How do we recognize when
there's problems on the system?

151
00:08:20,740 --> 00:08:23,770
How do we know if our system is
running slower than it used to or

152
00:08:23,770 --> 00:08:26,040
if we just feel like it's running slower?

153
00:08:26,040 --> 00:08:27,210
So how do we monitor that,

154
00:08:27,210 --> 00:08:31,330
how do we maintain, how do we keep
that system running in tip-top shape?

155
00:08:31,330 --> 00:08:32,130
>> Yeah.

156
00:08:32,130 --> 00:08:35,760
And lastly of course is actually
realizing that at some point sometime,

157
00:08:35,760 --> 00:08:39,300
hardware may fail us,
if not will fail us here.

158
00:08:39,300 --> 00:08:42,870
And so here we talk about the idea of
actually being able to take a look

159
00:08:42,870 --> 00:08:46,620
at some of the recovery options that have
always again been inside of Windows, and

160
00:08:46,620 --> 00:08:49,950
especially focusing in on the idea
of backing up our computers.

161
00:08:49,950 --> 00:08:51,970
>> Yeah, probably one of
the most important topics, right?

162
00:08:51,970 --> 00:08:54,370
Because when things fail and

163
00:08:54,370 --> 00:08:57,920
things go south, how fast can you get
them back up and operational again?

164
00:08:57,920 --> 00:08:59,600
That's what we tackle right up there.

165
00:08:59,600 --> 00:09:00,240
All right?

166
00:09:00,240 --> 00:09:03,330
So that's kind of a highlight
of the Windows 7 objectives, and

167
00:09:03,330 --> 00:09:06,520
you'll see that these are these
are a lot more than just,

168
00:09:06,520 --> 00:09:09,530
how do you fire up Internet Explorer,
how do you do end user stuff?

169
00:09:09,530 --> 00:09:14,760
This is, how do we run Windows 7 in
a corporate or enterprise environment?

170
00:09:14,760 --> 00:09:18,720
This is valuable knowledge for anybody
who wants to be a network administrator,

171
00:09:18,720 --> 00:09:21,290
a desktop engineer, even help desk.

172
00:09:21,290 --> 00:09:23,750
This is really where you get
your foundational knowledge for

173
00:09:23,750 --> 00:09:25,100
help desk operations.

174
00:09:25,100 --> 00:09:27,340
So really good information
to be found here.

175
00:09:27,340 --> 00:09:30,820
It's a great certification and it does
give you that foundational knowledge you

176
00:09:30,820 --> 00:09:33,090
need to deploy Windows 7 in a business.

177
00:09:33,090 --> 00:09:33,873
>> Right.

178
00:09:33,873 --> 00:09:37,865
>> All right, well, if that sounds like
something that you're interested in,

179
00:09:37,865 --> 00:09:40,464
stay tuned because we've
got more shows coming for

180
00:09:40,464 --> 00:09:43,138
Windows 7 as we jump through
all of our objectives.

181
00:09:43,138 --> 00:09:44,522
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don start the Windows 7 series by walking through the installation requirements and process. They also demonstrate dual-booting and migrating user profiles.
episodes.title: Installing Windows 7

topics.title: Installing, upgrading, and migrating to Windows 7

episodes.description: In this episode, Nathan and Don discuss and show the Windows 7 imaging process, this the most common process for deploying Windows 7 in a business process. They talk about and demonstrate the entire process including using VHDs (Virtual Hard Disks) in the deployment.
episodes.title: Deploying Windows 7

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue the Windows 7 series by talking about the hardware and application compatibility issues when moving to a Windows 7 environment. They show what happens during a failed driver installation and how to create shims for applications. They also dive into the local group policy editor (gpedit.msc) to configure software restriction policies and AppLocker.
episodes.title: Configuring Hardware and Apps

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don describe what is need to put a Windows 7 computer on a network and basic networking concepts. They discuss and show how to configure IPv4 and IPv6 addresses in Windows 7.
episodes.title: Network Connectivity

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie finish up network connectivity by taking a look at configuring the wireless NIC settings, they show the use of the control panel view of windows firewall and the Windows Firewall with Advanced Settings. They talk about some of the different ways to remotely manage Windows.
episodes.title: Network Connectivity Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Don tackle the most common user management tasks within a Windows 7. They demonstrate and discuss how to configure shared resources such as printers and folders. They also protect data through encrypting files and using NTFS permissions. They discuss what happens with permissions when moving and copying files.
episodes.title: Configuring Access to Resources

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Nate show how Windows 7 uses the User Account Control and how to control its behavior. They discuss authentication and authorization methods available in Windows 7 and demonstrate using BranchCache.
episodes.title: Configure Access to Resources Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie show the technologies involved with keeping Windows 7 protected and connected to our network resources. They show the use of BitLocker and BitLocker To Go as well DirectAccess and VPN connections.
episodes.title: Configure Mobile Computing

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie, discuss and show the basic tasks of keeping Windows 7 operating by taking a look at the options found in Windows 7. They also show how Window 7 can manage multiple hard drive disks.
episodes.title: Monitoring and Maintaining

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Wes take a look at monitoring Windows 7 through various tools included by default in a typical Windows installation. They demonstrate configuring event subscriptions and data collector sets as well as interpreting their output. They also discuss performance settings such as page files, hard drive cache and power plans.
episodes.title: Monitoring and Maintaining Part 2

topics.title: Monitoring and maintaining systems that run Windows 7

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie talk about the importance of backups for Windows 7 and the built options available. They show the use of system restore points and restoring previous versions of files as well.
episodes.title: Backup and Recovery Options
